At the same time, a strong surface high extending from the Great Basin into the central high plains was bringing in cold surface temperatures from the northeast. These features combined to create a band of heavy snow from eastern Luna County into northern Otero County where up to 9 inches of snow was reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A CoCoRaHS Observer reported 8.2 inches of snow 16 miles northwest of Las Cruces.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A positively tilted upper trough was dropping through the Four Corners region. At the same time, a strong surface high extending from the Great Basin into the central high plains was bringing in cold surface temperatures from the northeast. The northeast winds aided in producing enhanced upslope snowfall in Northeast El Paso where up to 6 inches of snow was reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A CoCoRaHS Observer near the foothills of the Franklin Mountains reported 6 inches of snow. Numerous other reports of 4 to 5 inches were received in the same general area.

Widespread snow spread across the Midwest the afternoon of January 5, 2015, with accumulations in Eastern Iowa beginning mid afternoon, and spreading into Northern Illinois mid evening. Widespread 4 to 7 inch amounts were reported, with numerous school cancellations on January 6th. Due to the cold air in place, the snow was fluffy in nature, but with little wind, blowing snow was not an issue.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters reported around 4 inches of snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters reported around 3 to 5 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong arctic cold front moved through the western Carolinas during the morning and afternoon of the 7th, bringing gusty winds and very cold air to the Piedmont and foothills. By late evening, sustained winds of 5 to 15 mph combined with air temperatures in the teens to yield wind chill values near 0. Although winds gradually diminished overnight, air temperatures fell to around 10 degrees in many areas by daybreak, and wind chills of 0 to 5 above lingered until temperatures began warming during late morning. However, temperatures remained at or below freezing in many areas throughout the 8th. Record daily lows were set in the Charlotte area on the morning of the 8th.

Low pressure tracked across eastern New England during the nighttime and early morning hours of January 18th-19th. The initial precipitation across Vermont was in the form of rain with air temperatures in the 30s to around 40 degrees. However, after more than a week of temperatures frequently near zero, road sub-surface temperatures were in the teens and 20s. Therefore, as rain fell and dusk approached, wet roads quickly became icy roads and lead to numerous vehicle accidents and closures of state and interstate roads. ||Rain changed to a heavy, wet snow across higher elevations and eventually in the northern valleys on the night of January 18th. Snowfall totals were 2 to 6 inches across northern Vermont with some locally higher in higher elevations, which led to scattered power outages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A heavy wet snow of 2 to 5 inches fell across Essex county, yet the main culprit was very icy roads due to rain on very cold road surfaces that led to numerous vehicle accidents.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A heavy wet snow of 2 to 4 inches fell across Franklin county, yet the main culprit was very icy roads due to rain on very cold road surfaces that led to numerous vehicle accidents.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked across eastern New England during the nighttime and early morning hours of January 18th-19th. The initial precipitation across Vermont was in the form of rain with air temperatures in the 30s to around 40 degrees. However, after more than a week of temperatures frequently near zero, road sub-surface temperatures were in the teens and 20s. Therefore, as rain fell and dusk approached, wet roads quickly became icy roads and lead to numerous vehicle accidents and closures of state and interstate roads. ||Rain changed to a heavy, wet snow across higher elevations and eventually in the northern valleys on the night of January 18th. Snowfall totals were 2 to 6 inches across northern Vermont with some locally higher in higher elevations, which led to scattered power outages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A heavy wet snow of 1 to 3 inches fell across Windsor county, yet the main culprit was very icy roads due to rain on very cold road surfaces that led to numerous vehicle accidents.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm air advection showers developed over Northeast Arkansas and the Missouri Bootheel during the morning hours of January 11th, 2015. Temperatures were at or below freezing due to an arctic air mass in place. This allowed precipitation to fall as freezing rain. Light icing occurred on trees, vehicles, and elevated roadways. Several accidents were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light freezing rain occurred across the county during the morning hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic high pressure, associated with record or near record surface pressure, settled into the mid Missouri River Valley during the early morning on the 7th. The combination of arctic air with actual air temperatures from 5 below to 5 above zero, and winds of 15 to 30 mph with gusts to near 40 mph created wind chill values of 15 to 25 below zero starting in the early morning on the 7th continuing through the early afternoon in many areas.

Severe or greater drought conditions continued to plague central and western portions of north Texas during January of 2015.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe/D2 drought conditions covered all of Bosque County at the beginning of January, with some of the far northern locations even being classified under Extreme/D3. By the end of the month, only the northern half of the county was listed under Severe/D2 drought, with the southern half having improved to D1/Moderate Drought.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe or greater drought conditions continued to plague central and western portions of north Texas during January of 2015.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Navarro County was affected by Severe/D2 Drought across the northwestern quarter of the county for all of January, 2015. The rest of the county was listed as Moderate drought or better.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Marginal Risk (SPC) day produced rather widespread wind damage across west-central Georgia during the late afternoon hours of the 26th.  An EF-1 tornado was confirmed north of Warm Springs in Meriwether county.  An upper level wave moving east from AL/Gulf coast region spawned widespread convection that became an evident QLCS that tracked west to east across GA during the afternoon hours.  The most intense/severe storms were generally south of I-20 and west of I-75.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Amateur radio operator reported a power transformer and tree down on house.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For the second time in a week, bitterly cold weather and dangerous wind chills were reported across the area.  The coldest temperatures since the January 1994 arctic outbreak were reported across Northeast Ohio.  Cleveland's low of minus 17 on the 20th was the coldest temperature ever recorded in February and tied for the third coldest ever.  The morning low at the Northeast Ohio Regional Airport in Ashtabula County was minus 29 degrees.  The rest of the area saw low temperatures from minus 10 to 20 degrees.  Winds just before and after daybreak where strong enough to generate wind chills of minus 25 or colder for a few hours.  Conditions gradually improved during the morning hours.  Schools were once again closed throughout Northeast Ohio.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures colder than minus 15 combined with westerly winds to create wind chills of minus 25 or colder for a few hours.  Morning low temperatures at most locations were the coldest since 1994.   The low at Northeast Ohio Regional Airport was minus 29 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For the second time in a week, bitterly cold weather and dangerous wind chills were reported across the area.  The coldest temperatures since the January 1994 arctic outbreak were reported across Northeast Ohio.  Cleveland's low of minus 17 on the 20th was the coldest temperature ever recorded in February and tied for the third coldest ever.  The morning low at the Northeast Ohio Regional Airport in Ashtabula County was minus 29 degrees.  The rest of the area saw low temperatures from minus 10 to 20 degrees.  Winds just before and after daybreak where strong enough to generate wind chills of minus 25 or colder for a few hours.  Conditions gradually improved during the morning hours.  Schools were once again closed throughout Northeast Ohio.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures colder than minus 10 combined with westerly winds to create wind chills of minus 25 or colder for a few hours.  Morning low temperatures at most locations were the coldest since 1994.  The morning low at the Youngstown-Warren Regional Airport was minus 16.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the wake of a departing storm system, strong northwest winds brought yet another frigid Arctic air mass into the region during the evening on Thursday, February 19th.  With winds gusting over 25 MPH and temperatures dropping below zero, wind chill values were as low as 15 to 40 degrees below zero during the overnight hours and into the morning on Friday, February 20th.  ||By the late morning hours on Friday, February 20th, diminishing winds and rising temperatures allowed wind chill values to improve. However, it remained rather cold through the remainder of the day. ||With a nearly month long stretch of very cold weather, there were many reports of bursts pipes and water mains.  Over 100 water main breaks were reported in the Capital Region through the winter so far, mostly in the town of Colonie where the infrastructure was much older.

An area of arctic high pressure moved from Canada to the western Great Lakes on February 15th.  Very cold air surged into northern Ohio in response to this high and was accompanied by strong north to northwest winds.  The combination of sub zero temperatures and winds gusting to as much as 30 mph created very dangerous wind chills over most of northern Ohio.  Wind chill readings dipped below minus 25 degrees during the predawn hours of 15th and then continued for four to six hours.  By midday, wind chills were back into the negative teens with slow improvement the remainder of the day.  Winds finally lessened during the evening hours as the high approached from the northwest.  By daybreak on the 16th, the high was centered over the Upper Ohio Valley resulting in clear skies and another frigid night.  Lows on the 15th were mainly 5 to 10 degrees below zero but most of the area dipped below minus 10 on the 16th.  The coldest wind chill reported was minus 30 at Toledo Express Airport (Lucas County) with minus 29 at the Northeast Ohio Regional Airport in Ashtabula County.  Fortunately all of the schools in northern Ohio were closed on the 16th for the Presidents Day Holiday.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sub zero temperatures and winds gusting to as much as 30 mph caused winds chills to get as cold as minus 30 degrees during the morning of February 15th.  Winds lessened during the evening of the 15th allowing low temperatures on the 16th to dip to minus 10 or colder most areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure tracked through the area.  Conditions were favorable for snow production.  Even the valley had significant snow over the 2 day period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observer recorded 4 inches of snow in Kingston.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure tracked through the area.  Conditions were favorable for snow production.  Even the valley had significant snow over the 2 day period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An automated observation recorded 4.5 inches of snow in White Pine.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system across Southern New Mexico/Northern Mexico began opening up and moved into the Texas Hill Country late on the 2nd and during the early morning hours of the 3rd. A strong upper level jet streak rounded the base of this trough from old Mexico into Southern Texas and into the Lower Mississippi Valley early on the 3rd as well. At the surface, a low pressure system formed off the Southeast Texas coast and moved North Northeast from Southeast Texas into Northwest Louisiana with a returning warm front from the coastal parishes of Louisiana. Heavy rainfall developed along and north of the Interstate 30 corridor of Northeast Texas, Southeast Oklahoma and Southwest Arkansas while strong to severe thunderstorms developed across portions of East Central Texas and Northern Louisiana along and in the wake of the returning warm front. The result was wind damage from these thunderstorms in addition to some flash flooding north and west of the Interstate 30 corridor.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and powerlines were downed at the corner of Williams and Henry Avenue in Natchitoches, Louisiana.

At the surface, a low pressure system formed off the Southeast Texas coast and moved North Northeast from Southeast Texas into Northwest Louisiana with a returning warm front from the coastal parishes of Louisiana. EVENT_NARRATIVE: One tree was downed on Hwy. 1228 near Hwy. 34 northeast of Atlanta, Louisiana.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe or greater drought conditions continued to plague central and western portions of north Texas during January of 2015.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Coryell County experienced Severe/D2 drought conditions for the majority of the month, but began to see these conditions improve following some beneficial rainfall towards the end of the month.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic cold front moved through the southern Appalachians and adjacent foothills during the morning and afternoon of the 7th, bringing strong winds and very cold air to the region. By late evening, sustained winds of 10 to 20 mph combined with air temperatures in the teens to yield wind chill values in the 0 to -5 range in the valleys. By daybreak on the 8th, air temperatures in the valleys were near 0 while the high elevations were well below 0. Wind chill values during this time ranged from 0 to -15 across the valleys, while stronger winds and colder temperatures likely yielded values as low as -50 across the high elevations of the Smokies and Balsams. The very low wind chills abated throughout the 8th, as temperatures warmed and winds diminished. However, air temperatures remained below freezing throughout the 8th.

An upper level low pressure system across Southern New Mexico/Northern Mexico began opening up and moved into the Texas Hill Country late on the 2nd and during the early morning hours of the 3rd. A strong upper level jet streak rounded the base of this trough from old Mexico into Southern Texas and into the Lower Mississippi Valley early on the 3rd as well. At the surface, a low pressure system formed off the Southeast Texas coast and moved North Northeast from Southeast Texas into Northwest Louisiana with a returning warm front from the coastal parishes of Louisiana. Heavy rainfall developed along and north of the Interstate 30 corridor of Northeast Texas, Southeast Oklahoma and Southwest Arkansas while strong to severe thunderstorms developed across portions of East Central Texas and Northern Louisiana along and in the wake of the returning warm front. The result was wind damage from these thunderstorms in addition to some flash flooding north and west of the Interstate 30 corridor.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two trees were blown down on Hwy. 126 in Sikes.  The roof was also blown off a carport in Sikes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a colder airmass in place and low pressure moving northward off the East Coast produced freezing rain and freezing drizzle across portions of central and eastern Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ice amount of .10 inch to .15 inch was reported.

Behind an Arctic cold front, very cold temperatures moved into the region from Canada for the overnight hours between Friday, January 30th and Saturday, January 31st.  Temperatures dropped to zero to 10 degrees below zero in many locations.  ||With gusty northwest winds in place, wind chill values dropped to 15 to 30 degrees below zero.  With these cold conditions in place, many cities and towns opened warming shelters.  ||With gusty winds diminishing during the day on Saturday, January 31st, wind chill values improved, although temperatures remained rather frigid through the day.

An area of very strong arctic High Pressure drifted south across the Northern Plains on January 7th and 8th.  This ushered very cold air into the upper Ohio Valley.  Northwest winds of 10 to 20 mph accompanied the cold air and they combined to create very dangerous wind chills.  Wind chills dipped below minus 25 degrees during the early morning hours of January 8th over much of Northwest and North-Central Ohio.  Low temperatures on the morning of the 8th were well below zero all areas with -5 at Toledo and -7 at Mansfield.  Wind chills remained colder than minus 25 through mid morning and then climbed into the negative teens by early afternoon.  Schools across the area were closed on both the 7th and 8th because of the dangerous wind chills.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chills dipped to minus 25 degrees during the predawn hours of January 8th.  Wind chills remained at or below minus 25 through mid morning and then slowly climbed into the negative teens during the afternoon.  All of the schools in the county were closed because of the bitter cold.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the morning of January 14th, considerable low level moisture lingered across the south central deserts following the passage of a wet winter weather system. Clear skies and light winds allowed areas of dense fog to develop, primarily across portions of western Pinal county. Some of the densest fog affected the areas around and to the south of Casa Grande; visibilities dropped well below one quarter of a mile and created very hazardous driving conditions. A serious automobile accident occurred in Casa Grande as a result of the dense fog, resulting in 2 fatalities and 2 injuries. A Dense Fog Advisory was issued for northwest Pinal county from 0500MST until 0900MST which included the community of Casa Grande.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Areas of dense fog developed in the Casa Grande area during the early morning hours on January 14th, a result of lingering low level moisture from a recent wet winter storm combined with clear skies. According to local law enforcement, visibility dropped to a few hundred feet across portions of Casa Grande at 0500MST and the dense fog persisted into the late morning hours. The fog created very hazardous driving conditions for area motorists, especially during the morning rush hour.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A tight surface pressure gradient resulted in very strong winds through the Judith gap area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sustained winds of 40 mph were recorded across the Judith Gap area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic front moved into the Billings Forecast Area during the late evening hours on the 2nd. Precipitation initially fell as light rain then freezing rain as temperatures dropped during the late evening hours on the 2nd into the early morning hours of the 3rd. The rain then changed to snow and accumulated on already icy road surfaces. Icy road conditions continued for the next week to ten days.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 6 to 8 inches occurred across the area. Interstate 90 south of Sheridan was closed for a period of time.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall around 5 inches was reported along with strong winds resulting in reduced visibilities of a quarter mile at times.

Snow accumulated 4 to 7 inches in Jackson County of southwest Minnesota from early morning to early afternoon of February 25th. Lesser snow accumulations were reported further west in southwest Minnesota. The snow was accompanied by northeast winds gusting to 30 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated 4 to 7 inches, including 6.5 inches 7 miles south of Alpha. The snow was accompanied by northeast winds gusting to 30 mph which caused areas of blowing snow, reducing visibility to 1/4 mile at times.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated 4 to 7 inches in Jackson County of southwest Minnesota from early morning to early afternoon of February 25th. Lesser snow accumulations were reported further west in southwest Minnesota. The snow was accompanied by northeast winds gusting to 30 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated 2 to 4 inches. Northeast winds gusting to 30 mph caused areas of blowing snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated 4 to 7 inches in Jackson County of southwest Minnesota from early morning to early afternoon of February 25th. Lesser snow accumulations were reported further west in southwest Minnesota. The snow was accompanied by northeast winds gusting to 30 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated 2 to 4 inches, including 3 inches 4 miles north of Currie. Northeast winds gusting to 30 mph caused areas of blowing snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic cold front pushed across Vermont during the afternoon hours of January 7th with plummeting temperatures and brisk, strong winds (15 to 30+ mph) causing dangerously cold wind chills of 25 to 40 degrees below zero during the evening of January 7th into the morning hours of January 8th. These dangerously cold wind chills lead to delayed school openings of 2 hours or cancelled classes on the morning of January 8th. Actual minimum ambient temperatures on the morning of January 8th were 15 to 30 below zero across northern New York. Observed wind chills in the mountains ranged from 40 to 70 below zero.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures by early evening of January 7th were zero to 10 above zero with winds of 15 to 30 mph that created wind chills colder than 20 to 30 below zero through the overnight into the morning hours of January 8th. Actual morning low temperatures on January 8th were 10 below to 20 below zero in Addison county, mildest near Lake Champlain. Specific temperatures included; 21 below zero in South Lincoln, 20 below zero in Monkton, 19 below in Starksboro and Hanksville, 12 below zero in Salisbury and Middlebury.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure developed off the Delmarva peninsula on Monday, January 26th,  and intensified rapidly as it moved slowly northward through the 27th.  Snow spread northward across the region Monday night and became heavy on Tuesday, the 27th.   Winds became strong during the day Tuesday leading to blizzard conditions at times along and inland from the coast.  The snow persisted into Tuesday night in many areas with blowing and drifting snow.   Along the coast, large waves combined with a storm surge produced coastal flooding and splash over.  In Hampton, the Tuesday morning tide was 1.43 feet above flood levels (see graph below), inundating many streets on the bay side of town.  ||Snowfall amounts ranged from 10 to more than 30 inches across much of the southeastern part of the state.  Elsewhere, amounts were generally 6 to 14 inches with some lower amounts in the Connecticut River Valley.

An area of low pressure developed off the Delmarva peninsula on Monday, January 26th,  and intensified rapidly as it moved slowly northward through the 27th.  Snow spread northward and eastward across the State Monday night and became heavy on Tuesday, the 27th.   Winds became strong during the day Tuesday leading to blizzard conditions at times along and inland from the coast.  The snow persisted into Tuesday night in many areas of western Maine. ||The storm surge associated with the storm, combined with high seas, caused coastal flooding, erosion, and splash over along the southwest coast of Maine.   Portlands tide gauge peaked at 12.32 feet at 4:18 am on the 27th, about 4 inches above flood levels (see graph below).||Across much of western Maine, snowfall amounts ranged from 10 to more than 30 inches with the highest amounts along and inland from the coast.  The northern mountains generally saw snowfall in the 6 to 10 inch range.  Below are some of the higher 2-day snowfall amounts (in inches) for western Maine Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Once blizzard conditions subsided, snow and blowing snow continued into the early morning of the 28th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick-moving Alberta Clipper brought a quick burst of snow, strong winds, reduced visibilities, and significant blowing snow to the region late January 8th into January 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periods of snow during the late afternoon hours of January 8th into the early morning hours of January 9th accumulated to between 2 and 3 inches. However, wind gusts ranging between 30 and 40 mph in tandem with the falling snow created whiteout conditions at times. Significant blowing and drifting of the snow created additional travel problems across mainly open and rural areas into the day on Friday. There were reports of slide-offs and accidents across the region, along with numerous school delays and closings.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A swell from a strong low far northwest of the islands generated surf of 10 to 20 feet along the north-facing shores of Niihau, Kauai, Oahu, Molokai, and Maui; and 8 to 15 feet along the west-facing shores of Niihau, Kauai, Oahu, and Molokai. There were no reports of serious injuries or property damage.

An Alberta Clipper brought a quick round of snow to central Indiana during the evening of January 5 and the early morning hours of January 6. The snow combined with the cold temperatures caused roads to become slick and hazardous for the morning commute. Snowfall amounts were heaviest north of Indianapolis, quickly tapering off to less than an inch south of Indianapolis.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall accumulation of 5.7 inches was reported from 2.6 miles northeast of McCordsville. No other information on impacts were received.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance produced freezing rain across central Indiana during the evening of January 11 and early morning of January 12 across central Indiana. Most of the freezing rain fell north of I-70, where 0.1 to 0.2 inches of ice were common. Temperatures around freezing helped keep areas south of I-70 from accumulating a lot of ice. As colder air moved in during the early morning of January 12, some accumulating light snow fell across far northern sections of central Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three tenths of an inch of freezing rain had accumulated in the Anderson area by within an hour after midnight during the early morning of the 12th of January. No other impacts were noted.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Light snow fell north of Interstate 80 in Iowa and Illinois, totaling 1 to 2 inches. Early in the evening, an arctic cold front swept through from west to east, producing strong winds and a short period of convective snow showers. This combined to produce a period of blowing snow with visibility well under a mile, and near zero for brief times.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blowing snow reduced visibility to under 1 mile, with brief near zero visibility in snow showers and strong wind gusts of 40 to 50 mph.

This combined to produce a period of blowing snow with visibility well under a mile, and near zero for brief times.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread snow spread across the Midwest the afternoon of January 5, 2015, with accumulations in Eastern Iowa beginning mid afternoon, and spreading into Northern Illinois mid evening. Widespread 4 to 7 inch amounts were reported, with numerous school cancellations on January 6th. Due to the cold air in place, the snow was fluffy in nature, but with little wind, blowing snow was not an issue.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters reported 6 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick-moving Alberta Clipper brought a quick burst of snow, strong winds, reduced visibilities, and significant blowing snow to the region late January 8th into January 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periods of snow during the late afternoon hours of January 8th into the early morning hours of January 9th only accumulated to around inch. However, wind gusts ranging between 30 and 50 mph in tandem with the falling snow created whiteout conditions at times. Significant blowing and drifting of the snow created additional travel problems across mainly open and rural areas into the day on Friday. There were reports of slide-offs and accidents across the region, along with numerous school delays and closings.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure developed off the Delmarva peninsula on Monday, January 26th,  and intensified rapidly as it moved slowly northward through the 27th.  Snow spread northward across the region Monday night and became heavy on Tuesday, the 27th.   Winds became strong during the day Tuesday leading to blizzard conditions at times along and inland from the coast.  The snow persisted into Tuesday night in many areas with blowing and drifting snow.   Along the coast, large waves combined with a storm surge produced coastal flooding and splash over.  In Hampton, the Tuesday morning tide was 1.43 feet above flood levels (see graph below), inundating many streets on the bay side of town.  ||Snowfall amounts ranged from 10 to more than 30 inches across much of the southeastern part of the state.  Elsewhere, amounts were generally 6 to 14 inches with some lower amounts in the Connecticut River Valley.

A light, fluffy one to two inches of snow fell on top of the snowcover from the February 16 winter storm. The new snow produced a fresh coating on top of already cleared roads, and additional snow on top of unplowed streets and back roads. Gusty winds caused some blowing of the snow. A disturbance in the upper levels of the atmosphere moved southeast across the Lower Ohio Valley. The fast-moving disturbance had little moisture to work with, but it was strong enough to squeeze out minor snow accumulations.

An arctic cold front pushed across Vermont during the afternoon hours of January 7th with plummeting temperatures and brisk, strong winds (15 to 30+ mph) causing dangerously cold wind chills of 25 to 40 degrees below zero during the evening of January 7th into the morning hours of January 8th. These dangerously cold wind chills lead to delayed school openings of 2 hours or cancelled classes on the morning of January 8th. Actual minimum ambient temperatures on the morning of January 8th were 15 to 30 below zero across northern New York. Observed wind chills in the mountains ranged from 40 to 70 below zero.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures by early evening of January 7th were zero to 10 above zero with winds of 15 to 30 mph that created wind chills colder than 20 to 30 below zero through the overnight into the morning hours of January 8th. Actual morning low temperatures on January 8th were 10 below to 20 below zero in Windsor county, including 21 degrees below zero in Rochester, 17 below zero in Pomfret, 16 below zero in Woodstock, and Weston, 15 below zero in Hartford, North Hartland and Ludlow, 13 below zero in Bethel, Weathersfield and Quechee with 12 below zero in Springfield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of weak low pressure systems and frontal boundaries delivered a mix of snow, sleet and freezing rain during the evening of January 3rd and eventually changed to rain during the morning of January 4th. Widespread snowfall of 2 to 4 inches was common along with up to a tenth of an inch of icing. In Northeast Vermont, widespread snowfall was 3 to 7 inches with up to one-quarter of an inch of ice.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread 3 to 7 inches of snow along with up to one quarter of an inch of ice occurred.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of weak low pressure systems and frontal boundaries delivered a mix of snow, sleet and freezing rain during the evening of January 3rd and eventually changed to rain during the morning of January 4th. Widespread snowfall of 2 to 4 inches was common along with up to a tenth of an inch of icing. In Northeast Vermont, widespread snowfall was 3 to 7 inches with up to one-quarter of an inch of ice.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread 3 to 7 inches of snow along with up to one quarter of an inch of ice occurred.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A tightened pressure gradient along the Rocky Mountain Front caused strong winds to develop and become gusty. The strongest winds occurred along the Northern Rocky Mountain Front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High sustained winds, measured at 38KT (44MPH), were reported 3 mi SW of Cut Bank, MT at the Cut Bank airport ASOS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A tightened pressure gradient along the Rocky Mountain Front caused strong winds to develop and become gusty. The strongest winds occurred along the Northern Rocky Mountain Front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High sustained winds, measured at 35KT (40MPH), were reported 8 mi WNW of Whitlash, MT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A tightened pressure gradient along the Rocky Mountain Front caused strong winds to develop and become gusty. The strongest winds occurred along the Northern Rocky Mountain Front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High wind gusts, measured at 50KT (58MPH), were reported 2 mi SSE of Geyser, MT at the Geyser DOT sensor.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A tightened pressure gradient along the Rocky Mountain Front caused strong winds to develop and become gusty. The strongest winds occurred along the Northern Rocky Mountain Front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High wind gusts, measured at 51KT (59MPH), were reported 29 mi SE of Lewistown, MT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Alberta Clipper weather system was enhanced by Lake Michigan moisture and brought heavy snow and strong winds that resulted in considerable blowing and drifting snow and very hazardous travel conditions.  There were many reports of 8 to 14 inches of snow, with the heaviest snow occurring near to mainly west of US-131.  Wind gusts reached 40 to 55 mph, highest near the Lake Michigan shoreline where the heaviest snow fell, which caused extensive blowing and drifting of snow.  A 193 car pileup occurred on Interstate 94 near Galesburg, between Kalamazoo and Battle Creek during the early afternoon hours of Friday January 9th, where visibility was reduced to near zero at times in heavy lake effect snow bands and blowing snow.  One fatality occurred in this accident.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts ranged from 10 to 12 inches with locally higher amounts in excess of a foot, along with a considerable amount of blowing and drifting snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deepening low pressure tracked from western Lake Erie across far southern Ontario to Quebec dragging a cold front across the region. Strong winds increased to near 60 mph about two to three hours after the cold front passage. The strong winds downed trees and wires across western New York. Scattered power outages resulted. Some specific damage locations included:  Richmond Ave in Niagara Falls, Telegraph Road in Shelby, St. Paul Boulevard in Irondequoit, Baker and Braunview Roads in Orchard Park, Lockport Road in Oakfield and Shortmond Road in Ripley.
A mix of freezing rain, sleet and snow fell on southeast New Mexico and west Texas as an arctic airmass resided over the region, and ahead of a slow moving upper trough.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Oncor Utilities reported 3,100 customers without power, and Sharyland reported 800 customers without power from down power lines due to icing.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mix of freezing rain, sleet and snow fell on southeast New Mexico and west Texas as an arctic airmass resided over the region, and ahead of a slow moving upper trough.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Oncor Utilities reported 7,500 customers without power, and Sharyland reported 800 customers without power across Ector County from downed power lines due to icing.  The Odessa Police Department reported streets becoming flooded from moderate to heavy rainfall and ice blocking drainage. ||Odessa Fire and Rescue reported numerous power lines down, in addition to high water rescues, and advised residents to stay away from Tom Green, Muskingum and Dixie streets between 52nd street, south to 16th street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mix of freezing rain, sleet and snow fell on southeast New Mexico and west Texas as an arctic airmass resided over the region, and ahead of a slow moving upper trough.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Brewster County Sheriffs Office closed Highway 67 between Alpine and Fort Stockton until further notice since a major power line which supplies power to Marathon and Terlingua failed due to icy conditions.  Restoration time was estimated for 1200 LST January 3rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mix of freezing rain, sleet and snow fell on southeast New Mexico and west Texas as an arctic airmass resided over the region, and ahead of a slow moving upper trough.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roads were icy in Big Spring. They had a mix of freezing rain, sleet and snow with ice accumulations varying between one tenth and one quarter inch.

CZ_NAME: REEVES COUNTY AND UPPER TRANS PECOS
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mix of freezing rain, sleet and snow fell on southeast New Mexico and west Texas as an arctic airmass resided over the region, and ahead of a slow moving upper trough.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ice accumulation around 0.25 inch at the Interstate 10 and Interstate 20 split, which is 39 miles southwest of Pecos.  Ice accumulation was only around one tenth of an inch in Pecos.

Many mountain locations in southeast Idaho recorded 7 to 20 inches of snowfall on the 4th and 5th of January.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: SNOTEL snow amounts were 20 inches at Pine Creek Pass, 9 inches at Somsen Ranch, and 8 inches at Sheep Mountain.   A vehicle rollover occurred in Inkom on East Green Canyon Road due to icy conditions closing the road for two hours.   No serious injuries occurred.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Many mountain locations in southeast Idaho recorded 7 to 20 inches of snowfall on the 4th and 5th of January.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One foot of snow fell at the Slug Creek Divide SNOTEL.

CZ_NAME: BIG AND LITTLE WOOD RIVER REGION
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Many mountain locations in southeast Idaho recorded 7 to 20 inches of snowfall on the 4th and 5th of January.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: SNOTEL amounts were the following:  7 inches at Dollarhide, 6 inches at Galena Summit, and 15 inches at Vienna Mine.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Many mountain locations in southeast Idaho recorded 7 to 20 inches of snowfall on the 4th and 5th of January.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ten inches of snow fell at the Morgan Creek and Meadow Lake SNOTEL sites with 9 inches at Moonshine.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Eleven single vehicle accidents occurred on interstate 15 between Fort Hall and Blackfoot on January 24th due to freezing fog and drizzle causing icy roadways to develop.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eleven single vehicle accidents occurred on interstate 15 between Fort Hall and Blackfoot on January 24th due to freezing fog and drizzle causing icy roadways to develop.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Light snow spread across much of Middle Tennessee during the evening hours on January 26, followed by additional light snow showers in the early morning hours on January 27. Some locations in the Upper Cumberland region had up to 1 inch of snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Parts of Sumner County measured around 0.5 inches of snow. A CoCoRaHS station 10 miles northeast of Gallatin measured 0.5 inches of snow, while an NWS employee in Castalian Springs reported 0.4 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A swell from a powerful low far northwest of the Aloha State generated surf of 25 to 40 feet along the north- and west-facing shores of Niihau and Kauai, and the north-facing shores of Oahu, Molokai, and Maui; 15 to 25 feet along the west-facing shores of Oahu and Molokai; 10 to 20 feet along the west-facing shores of the Big Island of Hawaii; 10 to 15 feet along the west-facing shores of Maui; and 6 to 12 feet along the west-facing shores of Lanai and Kahoolawe, and the south-facing shores of Oahu.||Officials closed several beaches on the individual isles ahead of the high surf.  After the surf arrived, reports came in that indicated damages on the Big Island to: a wharf, massage huts near a beach, sea walls, a lifeguard tower, and water lines to restrooms; and on Maui, damages to the Kaloko Pond at Kaloko-Honokohau National Historic Park.  Also, the surging high water brought debris ashore in many locales that affected shoreline roads and parking areas.  The cost of the all the damages had not been calculated.  No serious injuries were reported.

A northwest swell caused surf of 10 to 18 feet along the north- and west-facing shores of Niihau and Kauai, and the north-facing shores of Oahu, Molokai, and Maui; and 8 to 12 feet along the west-facing shores of Oahu.  There were no reports of significant injuries or property damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure built in to the region behind a cold front ushering in very cold temperatures and moderate winds leading to sub-zero wind chill values in the North Georgia Mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Brasstown RAWS site reported wind chill values below zero from around 6 PM EST on the evening of January 7th until around 8 AM EST on the morning of January 8th. The wind chill values remained below -10 degrees from around 9 PM EST on the 7th until after 7 AM EST on the 8th, bottoming out around 2 AM on the 8th when the air temperature of 1 degree combined with a 12 MPH wind to produce a wind chill of -16 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As the blizzard event on January 3rd ended, the concern quickly shifted to dangerously cold wind chills. From the afternoon of the 3rd through the morning of the 5th, wind chill readings dipped to 40 below to 50 below zero.

As the blizzard event on January 3rd ended, the concern quickly shifted to dangerously cold wind chills. From the afternoon of the 3rd through the morning of the 5th, wind chill readings dipped to 40 below to 50 below zero.

A quickly moving trough moved through the Kansas City area bringing a period of mixed precipitation. Rain preceded snow and the warm pavement melted the snowfall instantly. A sharp cold front moved through while the roads were still wet, causing a layer of ice. Untreated roads became very slick and at least one documented injury vehicle accident occurred as a result of the icy roads.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roads were icy after light rain fell and light snow melted on the warm pavement. When a cold front came through the moisture froze to the pavement, causing slick conditions. A NWS employee was on their way to the office when they lost control of their vehicle on Highway 150, just west of the intersection with Highway 7. The car slid off the road and flipped in the ditch. The person was hospitalized for a short time before being released later that day.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: January 5th through January 10th featured a prolonged period of very cold weather and sub-zero wind chills. The most extreme and dangerous push of this arctic air occurred on January 8th when wind chills dropped to between 20 below zero and 30 below zero.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chills during the morning and early afternoon hours of January 8th ranged between 20 below zero and 30 below zero. This dangerous cold led to numerous school closings and delays across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: January 5th through January 10th featured a prolonged period of very cold weather and sub-zero wind chills. The most extreme and dangerous push of this arctic air occurred on January 8th when wind chills dropped to between 20 below zero and 30 below zero.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chills during the morning and early afternoon hours of January 8th ranged between 20 below zero and 30 below zero. This dangerous cold led to numerous school closings and delays across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system across Southern New Mexico/Northern Mexico began opening up and moved into the Texas Hill Country late on the 2nd and during the early morning hours of the 3rd. A strong upper level jet streak rounded the base of this trough from old Mexico into Southern Texas and into the Lower Mississippi Valley early on the 3rd as well. At the surface, a low pressure system formed off the Southeast Texas coast and moved North Northeast from Southeast Texas into Northwest Louisiana with a returning warm front from the coastal parishes of Louisiana. Heavy rainfall developed along and north of the Interstate 30 corridor of Northeast Texas, Southeast Oklahoma and Southwest Arkansas while strong to severe thunderstorms developed across portions of East Central Texas and Northern Louisiana along and in the wake of the returning warm front. The result was wind damage from these thunderstorms in addition to some flash flooding north and west of the Interstate 30 corridor.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were downed on Colquitt Road just southwest of the Shreveport city limits near the Derrick and Woolworth Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system across Southern New Mexico/Northern Mexico began opening up and moved into the Texas Hill Country late on the 2nd and during the early morning hours of the 3rd. A strong upper level jet streak rounded the base of this trough from old Mexico into Southern Texas and into the Lower Mississippi Valley early on the 3rd as well. At the surface, a low pressure system formed off the Southeast Texas coast and moved North Northeast from Southeast Texas into Northwest Louisiana with a returning warm front from the coastal parishes of Louisiana. Heavy rainfall developed along and north of the Interstate 30 corridor of Northeast Texas, Southeast Oklahoma and Southwest Arkansas while strong to severe thunderstorms developed across portions of East Central Texas and Northern Louisiana along and in the wake of the returning warm front. The result was wind damage from these thunderstorms in addition to some flash flooding north and west of the Interstate 30 corridor.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and powerlines were downed along Cooper Road in North Shreveport.  Powerlines were also downed at various other locations throughout Shreveport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked east along the Ohio River and interacted with an upper level disturbance to wring out 4 to 5 inches of snow. A distinct southern edge due to the track of the surface low produced little to no snow in the immediate Ohio River valley in southern Ohio.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near Waverly measured 2 inches of snow. The county garage 5 miles south of Piketon measured 1.5 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful nor'easter brought blizzard conditions to much of southern and eastern New England on January 26-27th. However in Vermont, snowfall was moderate across the region with snowfall totals ranging from a few inches in much of western and northern Vermont to 6 to 10 inches in southeast Vermont.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall across Addison county was 3 to 6 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure impacted the region between the afternoon on Saturday, January 3rd and the morning of Sunday, January 4th. Precipitation associated with the storm's warm front initially began as snow across all of western Massachusetts. However, as warmer air aloft moved into the area, the precipitation changed to sleet and freezing rain by the evening hours. ||As low pressure passed to the west over the Great Lakes, light precipitation continued through the overnight hours, mainly in the form of a plain light rain. A few spots within the higher elevations continued to see periods of freezing rain through the overnight hours. Precipitation tapered off to drizzle during the morning hours, with temperatures rising above freezing across the entire area. ||Mainly light accumulation of snow occurred, with about 1 to 4 inches in most locations. Light ice accretion from freezing rain of about a tenth to a third of an inch also occurred. The combination of snow and ice led to hazardous travel across much of the region.

As the blizzard event on January 3rd ended, the concern quickly shifted to dangerously cold wind chills. From the afternoon of the 3rd through the morning of the 5th, wind chill readings dipped to 40 below to 50 below zero.

Snow accumulating up to 7 inches was accompanied by blowing snow as a result of northwest winds 20 to 35 mph. The main impact of the storm was to cause difficulties in weekend travel for those who did not delay their travel plans. The storm began on January 31st and continued into the new month through much of February 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated 2 to 4 inches, including 3.5 inches at Windom. Accompanying northwest winds gusting to 35 mph caused a few areas of blowing snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A swell from a powerful low far northwest of the Aloha State generated surf of 25 to 40 feet along the north- and west-facing shores of Niihau and Kauai, and the north-facing shores of Oahu, Molokai, and Maui; 15 to 25 feet along the west-facing shores of Oahu and Molokai; 10 to 20 feet along the west-facing shores of the Big Island of Hawaii; 10 to 15 feet along the west-facing shores of Maui; and 6 to 12 feet along the west-facing shores of Lanai and Kahoolawe, and the south-facing shores of Oahu.||Officials closed several beaches on the individual isles ahead of the high surf.  After the surf arrived, reports came in that indicated damages on the Big Island to: a wharf, massage huts near a beach, sea walls, a lifeguard tower, and water lines to restrooms; and on Maui, damages to the Kaloko Pond at Kaloko-Honokohau National Historic Park.  Also, the surging high water brought debris ashore in many locales that affected shoreline roads and parking areas.  The cost of the all the damages had not been calculated.  No serious injuries were reported.

A squall line developed in advance of a cold front moving across Mississippi and Louisiana during the late morning and early afternoon hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A rotating wall cloud and funnel cloud were reported northwest of Tylertown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moisture returning northward over a cold airmass produced a brief period of freezing rain over southwest Mississippi during the morning hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A light glazing was reported on one bridge on Mississippi Highway 570 west of McComb.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A band of lake effect snow moved north across the Buffalo Metro area around Noon Thursday (8th).  As it received the full effect of the still wide open and relatively warm waters of Lake Erie, it stalled and intensified for a few hours before continuing further north and weakening later in the afternoon.  During this time, visibilities dropped to zero along with wind gusts to 45 mph.  This created brief blizzard-like conditions while dropping a quick 2-4 inches of snow.  Luckily, this occurred between commuting times, and by the evening the band had dramatically weakened over primarily Niagara County. Following the passage of a surface trough a heavy band developed over the Niagara Peninsula around 2am, quickly moving across Niagara County, and then over the Buffalo Metro area for the remainder of the night. This portion of the event produced snow rates near 3 inches per hour during the morning commute. A portion of the New York State Thruway was closed. During Friday morning, the band moved quickly south and lost its connection to Lake Erie for several hours until a new band started to form around noon over the Western Southern Tier.  This band grew stronger throughout the day, and by the evening snow rates of three to four inches per hour were once again reported in a 15-20 mile wide swatch, this time primarily along and south of Route 20A, affecting the Southtowns and ski country.  Many area roadways remained closed. By Saturday morning, some areas in the Southtowns had received as much as 20 inches of snow, most of it occurring in about a 6 hour period.   During Saturday, the band quickly weakened as it headed quickly to the north where if finally fell completely apart by nightfall.  Specific snowfall reported included:  23 inches at Attica, 21 inches at Wyoming and Perrysburg, 20 inches at East Aurora and Boston, 19 inches at Hamburg, 13 inches at Buffalo International Airport, 12 inches at North Tonawanda, and 8 inches at Corfu and Medina.
Another Arctic cold frontal passage brought more snow, lake effect snow and blowing snow and very cold wind chills to the region from the 8th through much of the 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observing stations across the county reported between four and five inches of lake effect snow through the period.  Northwest winds gusting between 35 and 40 mph also resulted in considerable blowing and drifting of snow and near zero visibility at times.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The residents of eastern Kentucky experienced one of the most significant winter storms in recent memory on February 16. The snow first began falling in our far western counties between 3:00 and 3:30 am on February 16, 2015. The snow slowly spread eastward throughout the morning and eventually ended during the early overnight hours of February 17th. The final storm totals ranged from 2 to 4 inches along portions of the Tennessee and southwestern Virginia borders, to as much as 12 to 15 inches along a central portion of the area from Estill county all the way over to Pike county. A large portion of the area received between 4 and 11 inches of snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A volunteer weather observer measured 1.6 inches of snow in Wellington at 7:00 am to mark the start of this major storm. Moderate to at times heavy snow fell throughout the day and into the evening. The storm finally began winding down around 10 pm. The highest final storm snow fall totals were measured in Frenchburg (11 inches) and Wellington (11.7 inches). Around 10 inches of snow had fallen across the county on average by the time the storm finally came to an end.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front pushed along by an upper level disturbance produced showers and thunderstorms.  A few of these storms became severe, producing strong to damaging winds.  A rather moist atmosphere contributed to storms producing heavy rain which resulted in some street flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree on Route 20 was downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Tropical Storm Bill brought tropical moisture to southern New England.  This combined with strong low level forcing and some modest instability to produce showers and thunderstorms across portions of the region.  While none of these storms became severe, flooding occurred with a few of the storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Weatherflow Observation site at Fogland recorded a 41 mph wind gust.  No damage was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level jet streak, unstable atmosphere and a warm front lifting north helped to fuel thunderstorms, some severe.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few severe thunderstorms were observed during the afternoon.

An area of arctic high pressure moved from Canada to the western Great Lakes on February 15th.  Very cold air surged into northern Ohio in response to this high and was accompanied by strong north to northwest winds.  The combination of sub zero temperatures and winds gusting to as much as 30 mph created very dangerous wind chills over most of northern Ohio.  Wind chill readings dipped below minus 25 degrees during the predawn hours of 15th and then continued for four to six hours.  By midday, wind chills were back into the negative teens with slow improvement the remainder of the day.  Winds finally lessened during the evening hours as the high approached from the northwest.  By daybreak on the 16th, the high was centered over the Upper Ohio Valley resulting in clear skies and another frigid night.  Lows on the 15th were mainly 5 to 10 degrees below zero but most of the area dipped below minus 10 on the 16th.  The coldest wind chill reported was minus 30 at Toledo Express Airport (Lucas County) with minus 29 at the Northeast Ohio Regional Airport in Ashtabula County.  Fortunately all of the schools in northern Ohio were closed on the 16th for the Presidents Day Holiday.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sub zero temperatures and winds gusting to as much as 30 mph caused winds chills to get as cold as minus 30 degrees during the morning of February 15th.  Winds lessened during the evening of the 15th allowing low temperatures on the 16th to dip to minus 10 or colder most areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For the second time in a week, bitterly cold weather and dangerous wind chills were reported across the area.  The coldest temperatures since the January 1994 arctic outbreak were reported across Northeast Ohio.  Cleveland's low of minus 17 on the 20th was the coldest temperature ever recorded in February and tied for the third coldest ever.  The morning low at the Northeast Ohio Regional Airport in Ashtabula County was minus 29 degrees.  The rest of the area saw low temperatures from minus 10 to 20 degrees.  Winds just before and after daybreak where strong enough to generate wind chills of minus 25 or colder for a few hours.  Conditions gradually improved during the morning hours.  Schools were once again closed throughout Northeast Ohio.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures colder than minus 10 combined with westerly winds to create wind chills of minus 25 or colder for a few hours.  Morning low temperatures at most locations were the coldest since 1994.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure built up over the region, resulting in light winds and clearing skies. Strong radiational cooling led to widespread temperatures dropping below freezing.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple stations reported temperatures below 32 degrees Fahrenheit.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Talanei News reported a drowning incident of a 31 year old male near the village of Faleasao during the afternoon time. Hazardous seas and surfs were results of an active monsoonal trough that moved near the east of Manu'a. There were Advisories for high surf and small craft that were issued for all of American Samoa prior to this tragedy. The Department of Police Service dispatcher confirmed that the body of the victim has not been recovered.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Department of Public Safety dispatcher confirmed a drowning incident of a male fisherman in his early 30s on December 28th. The victim was swept to sea and his boy has not been recovered. Strong swells and hazardous seas have prevented the Search and Rescue team from conducting their services to find the missing man. The Advisories for small craft and high surf were issued prior to this unfortunate tragedy. A strong monsoonal trough near the east of Manu'a was responsible for strong gusty winds...hazardous surfs and swells.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced damaging hail across parts of Adams, Arapahoe, Douglas, Elbert, Jefferson and Larimer Counties.  Hail sizes ranged from quarter to tennis ball size; the largest of which was observed in Elbert County.  Home and vehicles were damaged by the hail; windows and windshields were broken. In addition, trees were shredded and severe plant damage was observed.  In Weld County, a strong thunderstorm produced nickel size hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A 27 year old mother and her 13 month old daughter were found dead in a field near Bryant Irvin Rd and Altamesa Blvd in southwest Fort Worth, TX. The cause of death was listed as hypothermia by the medical examiner.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 27 year-old woman and her 13 month old daughter died of hypothermia with paradoxical undressing according to local news outlets. This occurs when the victim begins to feel hot in the cold weather and undresses unknowingly in an attempt to stay cool. The bodies were located about 500 yards from their wrecked sedan and the clothing was found nearby. Fort Worth Meacham airport reported a low temperature of 32 and a high of 40 that day.

CZ_NAME: CENTRAL LARAMIE RANGE AND SOUTHWEST PLATTE COUNTY
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very strong gap winds developed between Chugwater and Wheatland in southeast Wyoming.  West winds frequently gusted between 60 and 70 mph for several hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The WYDOT sensor at Bordeaux measured wind gusts of 58 mph or higher, with a peak gust of 69 mph at 24/0735 MST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system across Southern New Mexico/Northern Mexico began opening up and moved into the Texas Hill Country late on the 2nd and during the early morning hours of the 3rd. A strong upper level jet streak rounded the base of this trough from old Mexico into Southern Texas and into the Lower Mississippi Valley early on the 3rd as well. At the surface, a low pressure system formed off the Southeast Texas coast and moved North Northeast from Southeast Texas into Northwest Louisiana with a returning warm front from the coastal parishes of Louisiana. Heavy rainfall developed along and north of the Interstate 30 corridor of Northeast Texas, Southeast Oklahoma and Southwest Arkansas while strong to severe thunderstorms developed across portions of East Central Texas and Northern Louisiana along and in the wake of the returning warm front. The result was wind damage from these thunderstorms in addition to some flash flooding north and west of the Interstate 30 corridor.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported that part of a roof was blown off a house, two utility poles were downed and a large tree was downed on Tidwell Road north northwest of Columbia, Louisiana.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold arctic airmass filtered into the region in the preceding days of January 11th with temperatures mostly in the lower 30s.  An overrunning moist airmass resulted in the development of mostly light rain across Southeast Oklahoma, Southwest Arkansas and the Northern third of Northeast Texas.  After midnight on the 11th, this precipitation became light freezing rain but due to the temperature being at or just below freezing, ice accumulation was relegated to trees and elevated exposed objects including powerlines and some bridge surfaces. Ice accumulations were mostly near one tenth of an inch across the region.
A large pressure gradient produced very strong winds through the wind prone areas of southeast Wyoming.  Peak gusts of 65 to 75 mph were common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The WYDOT sensor at County Road 402 measured sustained winds of 40 mph, with a peak gust of 60 mph at 18/0310 MST.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The WYDOT sensor at Foote Creek measured peak wind gusts of 59 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic cold front moved through the southern Appalachians during the morning and afternoon of the 7th, bringing strong winds and very cold air to the region. By late evening, sustained winds of 10 to 20 mph combined with air temperatures in the teens to yield wind chill values in the 0 to -5 range in the valleys. By daybreak on the 8th, air temperatures in the valleys were near 0 while the high elevations were well below 0. Wind chill values during this time ranged from 0 to -15 across the valleys, while stronger winds and colder temperatures likely yielded values as low as -25 or colder across the high peaks. The very low wind chills abated throughout the 8th, as temperatures warmed and winds diminished. However, air temperatures remained below freezing throughout the 8th.

On the morning of January 14th, considerable low level moisture lingered across the south central deserts following the passage of a wet winter weather system. Clear skies and light winds allowed areas of dense fog to develop, primarily across portions of western Pinal county. Some of the densest fog affected the areas around and to the south of Casa Grande; visibilities dropped well below one quarter of a mile and created very hazardous driving conditions. A serious automobile accident occurred in Casa Grande as a result of the dense fog, resulting in 2 fatalities and 2 injuries. A Dense Fog Advisory was issued for northwest Pinal county from 0500MST until 0900MST which included the community of Casa Grande.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Areas of dense fog developed during the morning hours on January 14th across the very far southeastern portion of the greater Phoenix metropolitan area. Visibilities dropped below one quarter of a mile at times and led to hazardous driving conditions for area motorists, especially in communities such as Chandler and Chandler Heights. At 0725MST, a trained weather spotter reported visibility less than one quarter mile along Higley Road in Chandler Heights.

An arctic cold front pushed across Vermont during the afternoon hours of January 7th with plummeting temperatures and brisk, strong winds (15 to 30+ mph) causing dangerously cold wind chills of 25 to 40 degrees below zero during the evening of January 7th into the morning hours of January 8th. These dangerously cold wind chills lead to delayed school openings of 2 hours or cancelled classes on the morning of January 8th. Actual minimum ambient temperatures on the morning of January 8th were 15 to 30 below zero across northern New York. Observed wind chills in the mountains ranged from 40 to 70 below zero.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures by early evening of January 7th were zero to 10 above zero with winds of 15 to 30 mph that created wind chills colder than 20 to 30 below zero through the overnight into the morning hours of January 8th. Actual morning low temperatures on January 8th were 10 below to 20 below zero in Chittenden county, mildest near Lake Champlain. Specific temperatures included; 20 below zero in Underhill, 17 below zero in Nashville, Westford and Jericho, 15 below zero in Huntington and Richmond, 14 below zero in Williston, 11 below zero at NWS Burlington in South Burlington and 9 beloe zero in Shelburne and Burlington.

These dangerously cold wind chills lead to delayed school openings of 2 hours or cancelled classes on the morning of January 8th. Actual minimum ambient temperatures on the morning of January 8th were 15 to 30 below zero across northern New York. Observed wind chills in the mountains ranged from 40 to 70 below zero.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures by early evening of January 7th were zero to 10 above zero with winds of 15 to 30 mph that created wind chills colder than 20 to 30 below zero through the overnight into the morning hours of January 8th. Actual morning low temperatures on January 8th were 10 below to 25 below zero in Franklin county, mildest near Lake Champlain. Specific temperatures included; 27 below zero in East Enosburg, 19 below zero in East Berkshire and Highgate, 15 below zero in Fairfax and St. Albans.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic front moved into the Billings Forecast Area during the late evening hours on the 2nd. Precipitation initially fell as light rain then freezing rain as temperatures dropped during the late evening hours on the 2nd into the early morning hours of the 3rd. The rain then changed to snow and accumulated on already icy road surfaces. Icy road conditions continued for the next week to ten days.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 4 to 8 inches was reported along with wind gusts greater than 40 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure developed off the Delmarva peninsula on Monday, January 26th,  and intensified rapidly as it moved slowly northward through the 27th.  Snow spread northward and eastward across the State Monday night and became heavy on Tuesday, the 27th.   Winds became strong during the day Tuesday leading to blizzard conditions at times along and inland from the coast.  The snow persisted into Tuesday night in many areas of western Maine. ||The storm surge associated with the storm, combined with high seas, caused coastal flooding, erosion, and splash over along the southwest coast of Maine.   Portlands tide gauge peaked at 12.32 feet at 4:18 am on the 27th, about 4 inches above flood levels (see graph below).||Across much of western Maine, snowfall amounts ranged from 10 to more than 30 inches with the highest amounts along and inland from the coast.  The northern mountains generally saw snowfall in the 6 to 10 inch range.  Below are some of the higher 2-day snowfall amounts (in inches) for western Maine Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Once blizzard conditions subsided, snow and blowing snow continued into the early morning of the 28th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated 4 to 7 inches in Jackson County of southwest Minnesota from early morning to early afternoon of February 25th. Lesser snow accumulations were reported further west in southwest Minnesota. The snow was accompanied by northeast winds gusting to 30 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated 2 to 4 inches, including 3.5 inches at Worthington. Northeast winds gusting to 30 mph caused areas of blowing snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure developed off the Delmarva peninsula on Monday, January 26th,  and intensified rapidly as it moved slowly northward through the 27th.  Snow spread northward across the region Monday night and became heavy on Tuesday, the 27th.   Winds became strong during the day Tuesday leading to blizzard conditions at times along and inland from the coast.  The snow persisted into Tuesday night in many areas with blowing and drifting snow.   Along the coast, large waves combined with a storm surge produced coastal flooding and splash over.  In Hampton, the Tuesday morning tide was 1.43 feet above flood levels (see graph below), inundating many streets on the bay side of town.  ||Snowfall amounts ranged from 10 to more than 30 inches across much of the southeastern part of the state.  Elsewhere, amounts were generally 6 to 14 inches with some lower amounts in the Connecticut River Valley.

An area of low pressure developed off the Delmarva peninsula on Monday, January 26th,  and intensified rapidly as it moved slowly northward through the 27th.  Snow spread northward and eastward across the State Monday night and became heavy on Tuesday, the 27th.   Winds became strong during the day Tuesday leading to blizzard conditions at times along and inland from the coast.  The snow persisted into Tuesday night in many areas of western Maine. ||The storm surge associated with the storm, combined with high seas, caused coastal flooding, erosion, and splash over along the southwest coast of Maine.   Portlands tide gauge peaked at 12.32 feet at 4:18 am on the 27th, about 4 inches above flood levels (see graph below).||Across much of western Maine, snowfall amounts ranged from 10 to more than 30 inches with the highest amounts along and inland from the coast.  The northern mountains generally saw snowfall in the 6 to 10 inch range.  Below are some of the higher 2-day snowfall amounts (in inches) for western Maine Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Once blizzard conditions subsided, snow and blowing snow continued into the early morning of the 28th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Light snow fell north of Interstate 80 in Iowa and Illinois, totaling 1 to 2 inches. Early in the evening, an arctic cold front swept through from west to east, producing strong winds and a short period of convective snow showers. This combined to produce a period of blowing snow with visibility well under a mile, and near zero for brief times.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blowing snow reduced visibility to under 1 mile, with brief near zero visibility in snow showers and strong wind gusts of 40 to 50 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick-moving Alberta Clipper brought a quick burst of snow, strong winds, reduced visibilities, and significant blowing snow to the region late January 8th into January 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periods of snow during the late afternoon hours of January 8th into the early morning hours of January 9th accumulated to between 1 and 3 inches. However, wind gusts ranging between 30 and 40 mph in tandem with the falling snow created whiteout conditions at times. Significant blowing and drifting of the snow created additional travel problems across mainly open and rural areas into the day on Friday. There were reports of slide-offs and accidents across the region, along with numerous school delays and closings.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick-moving Alberta Clipper brought a quick burst of snow, strong winds, reduced visibilities, and significant blowing snow to the region late January 8th into January 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periods of snow during the late afternoon hours of January 8th into Friday morning accumulated to between 2 and 5 inches. Wind gusts ranging between 30 and 40 mph in tandem with the falling snow created whiteout conditions at times. Significant blowing and drifting of the snow also created additional travel problems across mainly open and rural areas into Friday afternoon, with a few roads becoming impassible. There were reports of slide-offs and accidents across the region, along with numerous school delays and closings.

Short wave troughs merged across the deep south as a surface low crossed the local area from the Gulf coast region. Cold 500 mb temps of -17 to -19 deg C supported elevated instability in the hail growth zone.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny size hail was reported near Mora Road and Victory Road. Witness may have also seen a gustnado in the field.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low blow-out tides occurred during the early morning hours under strong offshore flow and along with low astronomical tide.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The St. Simons Island tide gauge at Village Pier reported a blow-out low tide of -6.57 ft datum level NAVD88.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low blow-out tides occurred during the early morning hours under strong offshore flow and along with low astronomical tide.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Fernandina NOS tide gauge reported a blow-out astronomical low tide of -6.13 ft NAVD88 datum level.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of weak low pressure systems and frontal boundaries delivered a mix of snow, sleet and freezing rain during the evening of January 3rd and eventually changed to rain during the morning of January 4th. Widespread snowfall of 2 to 4 inches was common along with up to a tenth of an inch of icing. In Northeast Vermont, widespread snowfall was 3 to 7 inches with up to one-quarter of an inch of ice.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall accumulations of 3 to 5 inches with ice accumulations up to a tenth of an inch were common.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall accumulations of 2 to 4 inches with ice accumulations up to a tenth of an inch were common.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain fell over the Midlands mainly north of I-20. Accumulation amounts were generally an eighth to one quarter of an inch in the central Midlands just north of I-20 and around an half an inch in the northern Midlands.  Trees and powerlines were down in many areas causing short term outages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reported 1/8 inch of ice in the northern half of Lee county including Bishopville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mix of snow, sleet, and freezing rain pelted the Midlands and Pee Dee regions.  Precipitation amounts were light with an inch or less of snow/sleet in the northern Midlands and Pee Dee with around an 1/8 inch of ice on elevated surfaces elsewhere in the Midlands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: EM reported light freezing rain on elevated surfaces  and trees across the eastern portion of the county. Amounts of up to 1/8 inch of ice were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mix of snow, sleet, and freezing rain pelted the Midlands and Pee Dee regions.  Precipitation amounts were light with an inch or less of snow/sleet in the northern Midlands and Pee Dee with around an 1/8 inch of ice on elevated surfaces elsewhere in the Midlands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sheriff and NWS employee reported freezing rain on elevated surfaces and trees with around 1/8 inch of ice.  Sleet was also reported with little or no accumulation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mix of snow, sleet, and freezing rain pelted the Midlands and Pee Dee regions.  Precipitation amounts were light with an inch or less of snow/sleet in the northern Midlands and Pee Dee with around an 1/8 inch of ice on elevated surfaces elsewhere in the Midlands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sheriff reported light snow across the county with a dusting on grassy surfaces.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Alberta Clipper weather system was enhanced by Lake Michigan moisture and brought heavy snow and strong winds that resulted in considerable blowing and drifting snow and very hazardous travel conditions.  There were many reports of 8 to 14 inches of snow, with the heaviest snow occurring near to mainly west of US-131.  Wind gusts reached 40 to 55 mph, highest near the Lake Michigan shoreline where the heaviest snow fell, which caused extensive blowing and drifting of snow.  A 193 car pileup occurred on Interstate 94 near Galesburg, between Kalamazoo and Battle Creek during the early afternoon hours of Friday January 9th, where visibility was reduced to near zero at times in heavy lake effect snow bands and blowing snow.  One fatality occurred in this accident.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts ranged from 6 to 10 inches across Kalamazoo county, with the higher end reports coming from the western half of Kalamazoo county.  WWMT-3 reported 10 inches of snow.  A 193 car pileup occurred in eastern Kalamazoo county on I-94 near Galesburg during the early afternoon hours of January 9th, where visibility was significantly reduced by heavy lake effect snow and blowing snow.  One fatality occurred.
